Class Compression

  • java.lang.Object
    • Compression
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    EqualLengthCompression, Huffman

    public class Compression
extends java.lang.Object
    Compression class handles essential tasks for any data encoding algorithm. A subclass of Compression benefits from common tasks like reading input from files, building a dictionary from input, encoding, decoding, and printing codes.

    • Method Detail

      • setupDictionaryFromString

        public void setupDictionaryFromString(java.lang.String alphabet)
        Builds dictionary from alphabet. First alphabet is split by "," and stores result in array. It then loops through this result and splits each element by "=". This results in a new array with the key in index position [0] and the frequency in index position [1]. Knowing the key and the frequency a new element is placed in dictionary. A similar process is continued for the entire alphabet.
        Parameters:
        alphabet - String with filtered alphabet. This means that keys are separated from frequencies by an "=" sign. Similarly, each key and frequency together are separated ",".

        Note: the last key and frequency in the alphabet should not have a ","

        Example: a=41,b=32,c=27,d=19,e=4

      • setupDictionaryFromFile

        public void setupDictionaryFromFile(java.lang.String fileName,
                                    boolean isAlphabetRawText)
        Builds dictionary from a file. The dictionary is built according to the file contents. If isAlphabetRawText == true the file contains raw text such as a Shakespearean play or a book. This being the case the file is filtered of non-letter symbols and all symbols are converted to lowercase. Additionally every symbol would be counted so each key would have a frequency. On the contrary if isAlphabetRawText == false then the file's content's is an alphabet which has every key and frequency separated by a "=" and similarly where each key and frequency together is separated by a ",".

        Example of "alphabet": a=34,b=23,c=9,d=7

        Note:

        • key = certain symbol
        • frequency = how many times a symbol is encountered
        Parameters:
        fileName - name of the file
        isAlphabetRawText - indicates whether or not the file's contents is raw text

        Precondition: fileName has ".txt" extension. Example: if fileName is "alphabet" pass as "alphabet.txt"

      • getInputFromFile

        protected java.lang.String getInputFromFile(java.lang.String fileName)
        Reads input from a file.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the file name
        Returns:
        all file contents

        Precondition: fileName has ".txt" extension. Example: if fileName is "alphabet" pass as "alphabet.txt"

        Note: returned String is not filtered of non-letter symbols

      • removeNonLetterSymbols

        public java.lang.String removeNonLetterSymbols(java.lang.String input,
                                               java.lang.String additionalCharactersToKeep)
        Removes all non-letter symbols (additionalCharactersToKeep are kept) using regex.
        Parameters:
        input - text to be filtered
        additionalCharactersToKeep - characters that should not be removed
        Returns:
        input filtered of all non-letter symbols and made lower case

      • encodeInput

        public java.lang.StringBuilder encodeInput(java.lang.String input)
        Encodes input using key's values from dictionary HashMap. Encoding is accomplished by retrieving every character's binary code from dictionary and appending it to result using StringBuilder.
        Parameters:
        input - input to be encoded
        Returns:
        input encoded with binary codes from dictionary HashMap

      • decodeInput

        public java.lang.StringBuilder decodeInput(java.lang.String input)
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Decodes input using key's values from dictionary HashMap. First, in order to decode loop through dictionary. While looping get the substring of the current key's length from our input. If the substring matches the current key's value then add the current key to the result and continue this process. This is guaranteed to work as no two Huffman codes have the same prefix.
        Parameters:
        input - input to be decoded
        Returns:
        input decoded with binary codes from dictionary HashMap
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if code is not found in dictionary

      • printCodes

        public void printCodes()
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Prints dictionary's keys and codes
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if originalAlphabetOrder is null
